metadata.case_name: State of Madras v. Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan & State of Madras v. C.R. Srinivasan

facts.text: State of Madras maintains four Medical Colleges with 330 seats: 17 reserved for out-of-state students, 12 for discretionary allotment by State, balance apportioned between four distinct groups of districts.

State of Madras maintains four Engineering Colleges with 395 seats: 21 reserved for out-of-state students, 12 for discretionary allotment by State, balance apportioned between four distinct groups of districts.

For many years before commencement of Constitution, seats apportioned between districts filled according to Communal G.O.: for every 14 seats - Non-Brahmin Hindus 6, Backward Hindus 2, Brahmins 2, Harijans 2, Anglo-Indians and Indian Christians 1, Muslims 1.
Selection from applicants from particular community from groups of districts based on academic qualifications and marks.
In Medical Colleges, not less than 20% seats for women candidates separately for each region, larger if qualified available.
Proportion in old Communal G.O. adhered to after Constitution commencement on January 26, 1950; G.O. No. 2208 dated June 16, 1950 reproduces communal proportion for Medical Colleges.

Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan applied to Madras High Court on June 7, 1950 under Art. 226 for writ restraining enforcement of Communal G.O. for Medical Colleges, claiming violation of Art. 15(1) and 29(2); belonged to Brahmin community, inquired and learned she would not be admitted.
Champakam Dorairajan did not actually apply for admission to Medical College.
State agreed to reserve seat for Champakam Dorairajan if High Court application succeeds; no objection to maintainability.
Madras High Court allowed Champakam Dorairajan's application by judgment dated July 27, 1950.
C.R. Srinivasan applied for admission to Government Engineering College at Guindy; passed Intermediate Examination March 1950 in first class, secured 369/450 marks in optionals for academic test.
C.R. Srinivasan filed petition under Art. 226 for writ restraining enforcement of Communal G.O. for Engineering College, claiming violation of Art. 15(1) and 29(2).
Madras High Court allowed C.R. Srinivasan's application by same judgment dated July 27, 1950.
State conceded that both applicants would have been admitted if selections made on merits alone.
State appealed High Court judgments under Art. 132: Case No. 270 of 1951 (Champakam) and Case No. 271 of 1951 (Srinivasan).
Classification in Communal G.O. proceeds on basis of religion, race and caste.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Communal G.O. laying down communal proportions for admission to Medical and Engineering Colleges violates fundamental rights under Article 15(1) and Article 29(2) of the Constitution.
Whether directive principles under Article 46 justify or override the provisions of Article 29(2) and permit maintenance of Communal G.O.

petitioner_arguments.text: Admissions regulated by Communal G.O. infringe fundamental rights under Article 15(1) and Article 29(2).
Denied admission on ground only of caste (Brahmin community).

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions of Article 29 to be read with Article 46 which directs State to promote educational interests of weaker sections, Scheduled Castes and Tribes; State entitled to maintain Communal G.O.
Article 46 overrides Article 29(2); no infringement of fundamental rights.
Petitioners not denied only because Brahmins but because Brahmin seats filled by more meritorious candidates and other seats reserved for other communities.

court_reasoning.text: Article 29(2) guarantees individual citizen right to admission into State-maintained or aided educational institutions, not to be denied on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them; applies if academic qualifications met but denied on prohibited grounds.
Directive principles in Part IV (e.g., Article 46) unenforceable by courts and cannot override enforceable fundamental rights in Part III; fundamental rights sacrosanct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Part IV subsidiary to Part III.

court_reasoning.text: Absence of provision in Article 29 similar to Article 16(4) for reservation of backward classes significant; intention not to introduce communal considerations in educational admissions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No equivalent saving clause in Article 29.

court_reasoning.text: Srinivasan secured higher marks than many selected Non-Brahmin candidates but denied seats reserved for other communities solely because Brahmin; denial on ground only of caste.
Classification in Communal G.O. proceeds on basis of religion, race and caste.

holdings.text: Communal G.O. violates Article 29(2) as it denies admission on grounds only of caste, religion, race.
Directive principles of State policy cannot override fundamental rights.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Communal G.O. violates enforceable fundamental rights under Articles 15(1) and 29(2); directive principles under Article 46 unenforceable and subsidiary.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected State's appeals against High Court orders restraining enforcement of Communal G.O., holding it unconstitutional under Articles 15(1) and 29(2).
outcome.relief_granted: High Court writs upheld, restraining State from enforcing Communal G.O.

key_quotes.text: The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unenforceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes supremacy of fundamental rights over directive principles.

key_quotes.text: The chapter of Fundamental Rights is sacrosanct and not liable to be abridged by any Legislative or Executive Act or order.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms inviolability of Part III rights.

key_quotes.text: Such denial of admission cannot but be regarded as made on ground only of his caste.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly applies Article 29(2) to communal reservations.
